text: Thank you, seconder. Thanks, Alana. All those in favour? So nothing arising. OK, but if we're all happy, we can move on. Economic Strategy Wellbeing Project.  Steve Tripp, Business Development Manager. Steve there?
speaker: suemilner

text: Yes. Yes, I am here. Yes. And since there's no public, you've got me to look forward to for the first 10 minutes.
speaker: stevetritt

text: Right. OK.
speaker: suemilner

text: Thank you. So I'll take my really short PowerPoint as read. I'll just  kind of acquaint you with where we're at with the economic wellbeing strategy. The strategy has been changed from an economic development strategy to an economic wellbeing to recognise a slight change in emphasis towards a greater wellbeing. And we're complying with the need for council to  adopts the four well-beings from government and the Local Government Act. So we've started the strategy. We're in targeted engagement with stakeholders, and this is part of engagement with stakeholders, business, elected members, councillors, community board, and iwi.  The aim is to work up a strategy for formal adoption in June by the Council. So the first stage, which is in progress, targeted engagement with stakeholders, and then drafting and stakeholder feedback. So we're still in the talk stage. I've started collecting  a few themes from our first few meetings, which I'm happy to go through shortly. So we've been gathering technical economic data. I can bury everybody in technical analysis and economic analysis. No two economists agree on the way things are looking. We're in a  interesting phase now with COVID has changed the expectation of business going forward and the business outlook. So it's a really appropriate time to update our 2012 strategy, which is, of course, now 10 years old. So our stakeholder and partner engagement is with  business owners, chambers, elected member, iwi consultative committee at the moment. And that's ongoing. The key sectors that we've identified loosely in the strategy, primary industry, food and agriculture, manufacturing, including agri-tech, technology, business professional services, education, high performance support, construction,  visitor and events. So those are the main sectors of interest. Our wellbeing priorities are across business and employment growth, the Maori economy, innovation and investment, workforce, education and training. So that's, yeah, that's it.  So, our aim is to work up a strategy that's fit for purpose in the current economic environment. And the strategy will align with the council's vision and community outcomes. So, over the last two years, we've engaged on community outcomes and we have a  a format for what is important to our community. So we want to ensure resilience and prosperity, economic well-being of the district, promote Waipara as an accessible and attractive place to do business, and identify opportunities for growth. So our engagement is with  partners, stakeholders, and elected members. We are not required to do a formal public consultation SCP process under the Local Government Act, but we know there's good community interest and business interest in our strategy, so we're looking for every opportunity to talk to people.  The emerging themes, let me list five of them so far, and then add a couple of sectors. So wellbeing outcomes, education, training, partnership, relationships, employment, and agriculture, primary industries. So added to that has been continued support for high performance sport,  support for events in the visitor industry. A suggestion from some quarters that we look at environmental sector businesses, education, aged health businesses, and the equine sector. That's a whole lot of sectors that I've just named. So if any, I can go through  the five themes in more detail, if you like. But let's just pause for some questions, comments.
speaker: stevetritt

text: Does anybody have any comments?
speaker: suemilner

text: Yes, so I do, please. Thanks, Steve. I just just this is probably the first I've really heard of the of this strategy. Just can you give me a little bit of more background of what this is that do my questions kind of around this? Do all district councils have a strategy similar to this?  And how much are you guided in what it looks like? You know, you were talking about the four well-beings. Do you have to be covering off those?  So just those couple of questions, just general background, because I'm struggling to understand it. And then finally, your emerging themes, most of them kind of hit me as sort of central government core business rather than district. So three sort of comments.
speaker: mikemontgomerie

text: Okay, I'll step through some of the themes in a minute. But yes, all councils, well, the majority of councils have an economic development strategy.  They all have business development, people like me, or economic development groups, to a greater or lesser extent. Some councils use, some councils are lucky enough to have a trust running an economic development agency, like Grow Wellington, ATEED in Auckland, which is now called something else,  So yes, the four well-beings are enshrined in the Local Government Act, so council must give effect to the four well-beings, and economic well-being is one of those. So it's a statutory requirement that we have something around the strategy. Our current one is 2012,  It was created by a group of business stakeholders and elected members, quite a few workshops, and there's a copy on our website. I've actually done an outcome review from the original strategy, which is quite interesting to show how we've fulfilled the original strategy.  What were the other questions?
speaker: stevetritt

text: That's covered off. Usually just the final one was the emerging themes seem to me kind of central government business. In a lot of aspects rather than district, yeah.
speaker: mikemontgomerie

text: Yes, you might. You can say that and and partnership relations relationships is a big theme so. So.  We have the benefit of being next to a major metropolitan area linked with key corridors to Auckland. So it's important that WIPA contributes to outcomes in the regional and sub-regional economy as well. It's kind of a joined up approach to growth. So it's important that we work with central government and its agencies to get a good outcome for us.  In terms like, and the theme under employment, a lot of the businesses reported a massive skills and talent shortage. And we've got an environment of full employment, which makes finding workers difficult. So growing employment was important to our community and employment issues around youth training  Staircasing into employment was really important. Now, central government doesn't operate in our area really well. And so we've got to take the initiative around some of these issues. So we've got to manage our own partnership relations between business and council.  Our employment outcomes are important. We don't have to do everything, but we need to make sure that training as much as possible can be local. Not everybody needs to travel to a tertiary or to Hamilton for training. Things as simple as driver's license training. If left to the government, we probably wouldn't have any of that locally.  And our wellbeing outcomes, you know, many of our economies are taking a wellbeing focus, and that's a shift from measure for looking for added value growth outcomes, not just growth. And we'll be picking a range of kind of economic wellbeing indicators that kind of signpost our progress in that area.
speaker: stevetritt

text: I think, Steve, that is a really good explanation of the strategy. Just one final question before I go quiet. That outcomes review, have you published that?
speaker: mikemontgomerie

text: No, but it's a council document. I'm happy to make that available to you. It's quite an easy read. It's full of graphs and diagrams showing how well we've done. Be aware that it's about 50 pages.  I thought I did send it to community board members on Friday, but I'll do it again.
speaker: stevetritt

text: You might have just caught me out there.
speaker: mikemontgomerie

text: Yeah. So at the end of our economic development strategy, we'll have a kind of an activity plan as well. Things that we feel the business community and elected members feel that we  could, should be doing. I'm conscious about not over promising because I'm a team of one. So, but we, you know, we want to have a kind of, we want to have a strategy going forward that directs some of my activity.
speaker: stevetritt

text: Steve, I just wanted to say I was happy to hear you say environmental and sustainable business in there, because I definitely think that's something that we should be looking to support going forward, both in terms of businesses working in that space and making the businesses that are here more sustainable. So good to hear.
speaker: alanamackay

text: Yeah, yeah. And we're also working on our environment strategy at the same time. And I'm  I'm taking a look into the environment strategy as well, because there may well be themes or techniques that our businesses need to pull out of the environment strategy to make their own lives sustainable. I mean, the first sustainability challenge for business is to stay in business and be there in two years' time. The second challenge is to do the right thing.  by the environment. So we'll be having a look at that. I'll also be looking for businesses that work in the environment sector. It's not clear to me whether there are very many, but I'll be looking hard because, you know, that's a growth sector and we'd like to  we'd like to be doing our own thing in that sector as well.
speaker: stevetritt

text: Thank you.
speaker: alanamackay

text: Any other questions? Who'd like to move that we receive the presentation Economic Wellbeing Strategy of Mr Tripp, Business Development Manager? Happy to Sue. Thank you Alana. All those in favour?  Thank you. Thanks very much, Stephen. Yeah, I'm always available by email if you have any thoughts or other ideas.

text: In the next month, I need all the ideas that I can get. And this is the time to kind of make suggestions before we start writing the strategy. But there's plenty of time.  to comment or discuss the strategy down the track.

text: Thank you. The next item is the proposed guidelines for lighting the Cambridge Town Hall and Clock Tower. So let's go to that one, because that's quite an interesting one. You've done some work on it, have you, Manana?
speaker: suemilner

text: Yeah, Elise and I caught up with Hannah about this one.
speaker: alanamackay

text: Yes.
speaker: suemilner

text: Good evening Sue and the rest of the community board. Thank you for having me along tonight.  So we've included the report and your papers there. So I will take the report as read, but it does follow on from our discussions at the end of last year to create a set of guidelines that would be adhered to for applications for lighting up the town hall and also the clock tower as well. So I've worked with Alana and Elise to pull together the proposed guidelines.  So you'll see those there in front of you. So the criteria includes charities or community initiatives that Waipā District Council supports through funding or strategic partnerships, a private event that a town hall event has a town hall event booking and does not clash with preferential dates listed below, to mark a special national event milestone or celebration for a particular council run or partnered event, and as a symbol of respect or of solidarity with other global landmarks following guidance from central government.  And then, obviously, we've listed those preferential dates here that came up at the former meeting. So that includes Waitangi Day, Anzac Day, Easter, Matariki, Basil Day, Likanoi, Liberation and Armistice and Christmas. So we're just here tonight just to see if we can get those endorsed and recommended, and then they'll be going back to Council for the Finance and Corporate Committee.
speaker: hannahblake

text: Okay well I've got a question. A private event that has a town hall event booking and does not clash with preferential dates listed below. So if somebody has a wedding for example they could pay to light up the clock tower
speaker: suemilner

text: Elise, did you want to answer this one? This was maybe something we needed to discuss tonight and iron out in a bit more detail.
speaker: hannahblake

text: So we've put at the top, it's available to be booked by community groups and charities. So that kind of excludes a private event. However, I think it's worth discussing the potential merit of those  assets being available to be lit up by someone if they'd booked the town hall. And if I can just share my opinion, I understand there was some discussion at our last meeting that if they were available for private lighting, for private events, that that would potentially reduce the impact of lighting up the assets. In my opinion, I think having a vibrant CBD with a lot of activity,  would be a good thing. So if you drove through the town and it was lit up because there was a wedding on or there was a film theater or something, I don't see that as a negative thing. I see it as something that shows we have a vibrant township, vibrant CBD, and in fact would help to promote our town hall, which I think is good to promote. That is a really wonderful part of Cambridge. So we've left this intentionally vague  tonight so that we could just bring that idea to you all and see if there was strong opinion in regards to whether it remain exclusively for community groups and charities and then it would just be as simple as changing that note that says if  that you know the charity or community group needs to be aware if there's a private booking already happening in the hall and liaise with that with that group to make sure they're happy for it to be lit up because we don't want to light it up if someone's wedding is happening and they don't want it lit up so we just need to kind of make some modifications there but if if people are happy to that concept of there being available for private a private event  with the caveat that they meet the criteria around being able to meet the costs and they don't clash with any other of the preferential dates, then we can make it happen too. But I was happy just to, it wasn't clear where we were at with our guidelines. It wasn't really specific. And I thought we needed to probably nail down exactly what the expectation was there and then tighten this up, which we can probably do in this meeting without sending it back to council again.
speaker: elisebadger

text: And also whether it would be both the town hall and the clock tower, or whether they could be separated out. So if you were having a wedding in the town hall, you might just want to light the front of the town hall.

text: Yeah. Yeah. We probably could not one or both. Yeah.

And they may not necessarily be using the town hall. I just, I think- That's where I think we'd be clear with our criteria that it would be a town hall clock. That's the difficulty. And, you know, whether we actually set a really decent price on lighting up the town hall clock, you know,
speaker: suemilner

text: I think if we're clear with our criteria, let's say, depending on what everyone thinks, if we're open to it being lit up for a private event, then it would need to coincide with the town hall booking. So I think that would preclude lighting up the clock tower for private events, but it would include lighting up the town hall.  in conjunction with a booked private event that didn't clash with the aforementioned dates. So I hear you, so it has to be a clear connection. But I don't think that's a problem, having people talking about what's happening in town. I think that's only a good thing. text: Good evening, everyone. Like Steve, I'm a team of one. And Bruce has left in the last couple of weeks. So the property services team is two down out of six and have been for some time. So resourcing is a real issue for us at the moment. Take the report as read. It's a report till the 31st of December, 2021. I'll just go some of the Cambridge.  Matt Constable's iPhone 2.  Lease and services agreement was sent to them a couple of days before Christmas, I think. So they're getting that legally reviewed at the moment and hope to get some feedback on that in the not too distant future. Cambridge Museum, the roof needs replacing. So at the same time we do that, we will repair or fix up some of the seismic issues.  One of the major issues that drives the percentage of MBS is the parapet. So when the roof's off, we'll be fixing the parapet back to the structure, which will increase the percentage of MBS. And we'll also look at doing something with the chimney. So they were two of the major items that issues in relation to earthquake prone building.  So that works on going Cambridge Water Tower. We've been dealing with Heritage New Zealand. I think we've got a plan now. We believe we can remove the tower and the steel work at the top before it completely falls off. But we have to put a steel frame up there.  which replicates the size and how the tank used to be. So we're working through that. C1, C2 and C3 growth cells. The major infrastructure corridors have been acquired in C2.  through the 3Ms block, and also an agreement's in place for the infrastructure corridors through C3, which is a joint venture between St. Peter's School Trust and 3Ms. There's a whole heap of other acquisitions that are ongoing in that area. Cambridge Road, Hamilton Road, urbanisation, that's pretty well done from a property perspective. We've just got one,  or two pieces of land to tidy up on that. And then Eric from Roding can get those works underway. Hicks Road, that's the walkway to the northern enclosure that has been closed for about three years.  Um, Mr. Knighton managed to work all the time through Christmas and managed to get it open on New Year's Eve. So credit to Gary for sorting that out when he was, should have been on leave. Um, Mungatowtrie road cycleway. So as you're probably aware, we purchased state 59 Mungatowtrie road.  which is about 19 hectares adjoins Waipuki. So that was the final piece in the puzzle that we needed to have a contiguous route to Waipuki for Tiawa cycleway. So,  We've got the land, it's just a matter of now getting the funding in the LTP to tidy up that bit of extra track. So you'll be able to ride from Fukunui Stud to Waipuki within the Waipa Council boundary.  So as you probably saw the cycle way to the northern boundary was opened the other day. So get on your bike and go for a ride.

But we tried our best, and unfortunately Bunnings went with the other party.
speaker: johnmiles

text: So are you satisfied with how the whole process went? Because from our point of view, it does seem like a bit of a miss. And fair enough, if it just got too expensive, I understand that. But from your point of view, was the process good? Was it clean? You know, did you go get every opportunity you could sort of thing?
speaker: mikemontgomerie

text: Yeah, well, we were in partnership with someone.  and that's made it stack up from council's point of view. We had valuation advice. We went in at a figure that we thought was a figure that would achieve that. We thought we had a better proposition being the council. You're paying 200 and something, $220,000 grand rent there. And we know it's a landlord that  you know, if it's a private person, they've got to step through a heap of hoops to, you know, personal guarantees and all those sorts of things. So council, in my view, is a better proposition from, you know, we're here for the long run. We're not gonna disappear. Yeah, so it's one of those things.
speaker: johnmiles

text: John, just to that point,  Obviously, that particular site was available for sale for a long time before we heard about Council putting an offer forward. Could it have been moved on sooner? Is there a reason it wasn't moved on? We did move on it when it was first there.

text: We looked at it. We didn't get to a stage where we made an offer because the price at that time was considerably higher than what  the actual price they were talking about in recent times. The shed's leasehold and the corner site is freehold.  So trim, trim, trim, lease, basically own half the Viaduct Harbour. They own the leasehold of it. Yeah, so I think Bunnings came, I don't know, but the price, the price was a lot more  in making it work for us in a year after it first went on the market. And I guess that's because Bunnings are sitting there, they are using it for storage at the moment for some timber, but at the time, they're paying 220 odd thousand dollars a year for no return. text: Kia ora tātou, te hei Māori ora ki a koutou katoa. I'll just take you through a couple of the highlights from our report this last quarter. It was certainly another busy one for our community services whānau.  Again, we continue to see high vandalism across our parks, now public toilets. As I described to SPMP yesterday, the damage has become what I would describe more intentional now rather than opportunistic with seeing things like arson and people bringing tools to cut and remove assets, way more graffiti and just a general disregard for  actually stick his belief at how some members of the community think that it's OK to sort of trash the assets and then leave a trail of destruction behind to be cleaned up. And as I just said, we're not sure of the of the reason why we're seeing this increase.  But one can only presume there's some sort of link to the fatigue and uncertainty of the last couple of years with COVID and now see potential escalation in the European countries.  We do have projects for some of our hotspots to address some of the issues that we've seen. We've always known that some of our more secluded or rural spots have a bit more higher vandalism, but as I said, that's even moving right into the urban areas now.  Pukimaku and Gaslight Theatre are two sites that we do have plans to do some more work in and we're working to get cameras in there. Some speed bumps have already gone into Pukimaku. There's some plan to go into Gaslight Theatre to slow the hoons that rip through there down a bit.  And then yesterday at the Strategic Planning and Policy Committee, they supported staff to look more closely at the Public Places By-law, which specifically for anti-social driving will be something that gives police and us a bit more teeth to, you know, catch these people and discipline them.  Libraries, just following on from what John was saying there, with that theme, we've had another very busy quarter. Quarter 2 did see the closure of the libraries while we were in Alert Level 4 there for a brief period of time.  But while we were in level 4, we were able to begin our click and collect service again. And then when we did open up in November and December, we saw some really high numbers of book issues through that period, which offset the lack of issues in October. When we moved to the COVID-19 protection framework,  We transitioned from the orange light to the red light, and obviously all of our council facilities required vaccine passports into the facility. So this did create a little bit of angst with some members of the public and the community, and the teams have done a really fantastic job of dealing with some of those difficult conversations. They're sort of the ones that wear the brunt of some of people's frustrations sometimes, so the team's done really, really well.  And even moving forward from when level 4 was, our click and collect service, especially in Cambridge, is continuing to see a strong demand and increase. I guess as Omicron kicks off and we start to move towards our peak, people are more inclined to use that service than otherwise.  In terms of our parks, our teams are struggling to recruit still. It's been a bit of an ongoing issue, especially for the parks team. Our reserve planner role at the moment has been vacant since early December, and it's one of our key roles to do a lot of our planning and future thinking work.  We're actually in the second round of recruitment for that role now. And we still have vacant mower operators and gardening roles. And to offset the vacancies in that thing, we've actually had to bring in some contractors to just help us keep up with level of service. So those are just a few highlights from the report. I'm happy to take any questions from anyone.
speaker: bradward

text: Anybody got any questions for Mark?

So we will, I'll be getting in touch with her next week to set up the fourth pop-up garden. And then we will liaise a date where we can do a mass planting.  autumn planting all the pop-ups and the new planting and digging the new garden. That might happen on a different date actually, but got together with the guardians of the existing three and everyone's very keen to stay part of the project and keep doing the money required. It's end of seasons, everything is looking pretty sad, but with the autumn rains we'll get planting and things should be looking good for the coming  autumn and winter harvest.

And so the daycare center, sorry, the early childhood center are going to look at doing sort of some chalkboards on the fence. They'll talk to their neighbors and whether or not they can erect a chalkboard and they can write up what can be harvested.  and then promote it through their network, like their sort of email out networks as well. So it's,  generally considered to be quite a positive thing to be doing in the community, and it will just keep finessing it and growing it, and it will develop its own presence in the community over time, kind of fed by the guardians, which is the goal.

So I'm gonna make a time to go into the museum and have a look at those and hopefully be able to share those with the community and help educate people on our sister cities. Also with the 70th anniversary of New Zealand-Japanese diplomatic relationships this year, the embassy has asked us among other areas with  Japanese sister cities to do little videos. So Graham Weber and Ayako and I have been working on those. So we've got a minute long little video just talking about the background and how the Cambridge Pohoro sister city was set up. So we've done a version in English that'll have Japanese subtitles and a Japanese version that'll have English subtitles.  So not only sharing that through the embassy, but also through our own social media, again, helping, hopefully, our community to understand more about that relationship.
